Post.title: Neural Networks for Machine Learning
Post._content: # ## - Recognizing pattern - Objects - facial - Spoken word - Recognizing anomalies - credit card transaction - Sensor reality - Prediction - stock price, - exchange rate - movie like ## - Linear neurons $ y=b+\sum x_iw_i $ - Binary threshold neurons $$ z=\Sigma x_i w_i \quad y=\begin{cases} 1&if\;z \gt 0\\ 0&otherwise \end{cases} \quad or \qquad \theta=-b \quad z=b+\Sigma x_i y_i \quad y=\begin{cases} 1&if\;z \gt \theta\\ 0&otherwise \end{cases} $$ - Rectified Linear Neurons 2 $$z=\Sigma x_i w_i, y= \begin{cases} z, &if\;z \gt 0 \\ 0, &\mbox{otherwise} \end{cases}$$ - sigmoid neurons $$ z=b+\Sigma x_i w_i \quad y=\frac {1} {1+e^{-z}} $$ ![nnml-sigmoid](http://p15i7i801.bkt.clouddn.com/86069ad24cfd3541f4b33070b67fd749.png) - Stochastic binary neurons $$z=b+\Sigma x_i w_i \quad p(s=1)=\frac {1} {1+e^{-z}}$$ ## - supervised learning * Regression * model class: $y=f(x;w)$ * 1/2 ![nnml-regression](http://p15i7i801.bkt.clouddn.com/93512d5be2aafca06ff3d058aff511b7.png) * classification - reinforced learning the output is an action or sequence of actions and the only supervisory is an occasional scalar reward._This is difficult_, The rewads are typically delayed so its had to know where we went wrong( or right) - unsupervised learning ![nnml-unsupervised](http://p15i7i801.bkt.clouddn.com/ada9c5e7fe1e06957b0797be4022d724.png) ## - Feed-Forward neural network ![nnml-feedforward](http://p15i7i801.bkt.clouddn.com/3053d06760561e6169f20829df15a358.png) if there is more than one hidden layer, we call them "deep" neural networks. - Recurrent network It is hard to train but natural way for modeling sequence, recent algorithm can be able to do this, this also can be used to predict stock price. ![nnml-recurrent](http://p15i7i801.bkt.clouddn.com/83abfe6f730b3ae61d9099ff0d5ff300.png) ![nnml-rnn](http://p15i7i801.bkt.clouddn.com/3a688df70ed6bf1e46d62a03402e2a39.png) > 20171218 LSTM - Symmetrically connected networks ## ![nnml-perceptron-arch](http://p15i7i801.bkt.clouddn.com/a1ba9669ccb220d05a8140bc8e0ca797.png) > how to learn biases using the same rule as we use for learning weights ![nnml-handlebias](http://p15i7i801.bkt.clouddn.com/d73047067e05f31a249dc755851602aa.png) > if the output unit is correct, leave its weights alone, if the output unit incorrectly output ![nnml-per-train](http://p15i7i801.bkt.clouddn.com/6b72ab6f556908380fcd6d5561d2e650.png) - __Zy=1__ perpendicular - $(w,b) \leftarrow (w,b)-(x,1)$ $(w,b) \leftarrow (w,b)+(x,1)$ ![nnml-adpateside](http://p15i7i801.bkt.clouddn.com/b109e1d1e4424d180575bb0f74e75906.png) - *just like penalty function* > : __ 1. Each time the perceptron makes a mistake, the current weight vector moves to decrease its squared distance from every weight vector in the "generously feasible" region. 2. The squared distance decreases by at least the squared length of the input vector. 3. So after a finite number of mistakes, the weight vector must lie in the feasible region if the region exist. ## > **right feature** Once the hand-coded features have been determined, there are very strong limitations on what a perceptron can learn. _The main question is : This type of table look-up won't generalize, it need too many feature_ __ > Group Invariance Theorem---Minsky and Papert can't learn to do this if the transformations from a group{}so it needs to use multiple feature unit to recognize transformations of informative sub-patterns. So,more important was all about how you learn **feature detectors, that's hidden units**. After 20 years, We know, we need multiple layer of adaptive, non-linear hidden units.
Post.raw: --- title: Neural Networks for Machine Learning date: 2016-06-07 13:26:48 tags: - - Geoffrey hinton - categories: AI mathjax: true --- # ## - Recognizing pattern - Objects - facial - Spoken word - Recognizing anomalies - credit card transaction - Sensor reality - Prediction - stock price, - exchange rate - movie like ## - Linear neurons $ y=b+\sum x_iw_i $ - Binary threshold neurons $$ z=\Sigma x_i w_i \quad y=\begin{cases} 1&if\;z \gt 0\\ 0&otherwise \end{cases} \quad or \qquad \theta=-b \quad z=b+\Sigma x_i y_i \quad y=\begin{cases} 1&if\;z \gt \theta\\ 0&otherwise \end{cases} $$ - Rectified Linear Neurons 2 $$z=\Sigma x_i w_i, y= \begin{cases} z, &if\;z \gt 0 \\ 0, &\mbox{otherwise} \end{cases}$$ - sigmoid neurons $$ z=b+\Sigma x_i w_i \quad y=\frac {1} {1+e^{-z}} $$ ![nnml-sigmoid](http://p15i7i801.bkt.clouddn.com/86069ad24cfd3541f4b33070b67fd749.png) - Stochastic binary neurons $$z=b+\Sigma x_i w_i \quad p(s=1)=\frac {1} {1+e^{-z}}$$ ## - supervised learning * Regression * model class: $y=f(x;w)$ * 1/2 ![nnml-regression](http://p15i7i801.bkt.clouddn.com/93512d5be2aafca06ff3d058aff511b7.png) * classification - reinforced learning the output is an action or sequence of actions and the only supervisory is an occasional scalar reward._This is difficult_, The rewads are typically delayed so its had to know where we went wrong( or right) - unsupervised learning ![nnml-unsupervised](http://p15i7i801.bkt.clouddn.com/ada9c5e7fe1e06957b0797be4022d724.png) ## - Feed-Forward neural network ![nnml-feedforward](http://p15i7i801.bkt.clouddn.com/3053d06760561e6169f20829df15a358.png) if there is more than one hidden layer, we call them "deep" neural networks. - Recurrent network It is hard to train but natural way for modeling sequence, recent algorithm can be able to do this, this also can be used to predict stock price. ![nnml-recurrent](http://p15i7i801.bkt.clouddn.com/83abfe6f730b3ae61d9099ff0d5ff300.png) ![nnml-rnn](http://p15i7i801.bkt.clouddn.com/3a688df70ed6bf1e46d62a03402e2a39.png) > 20171218 LSTM - Symmetrically connected networks ## ![nnml-perceptron-arch](http://p15i7i801.bkt.clouddn.com/a1ba9669ccb220d05a8140bc8e0ca797.png) > how to learn biases using the same rule as we use for learning weights ![nnml-handlebias](http://p15i7i801.bkt.clouddn.com/d73047067e05f31a249dc755851602aa.png) > if the output unit is correct, leave its weights alone, if the output unit incorrectly output ![nnml-per-train](http://p15i7i801.bkt.clouddn.com/6b72ab6f556908380fcd6d5561d2e650.png) - __Zy=1__ perpendicular - $(w,b) \leftarrow (w,b)-(x,1)$ $(w,b) \leftarrow (w,b)+(x,1)$ ![nnml-adpateside](http://p15i7i801.bkt.clouddn.com/b109e1d1e4424d180575bb0f74e75906.png) - *just like penalty function* > : __ 1. Each time the perceptron makes a mistake, the current weight vector moves to decrease its squared distance from every weight vector in the "generously feasible" region. 2. The squared distance decreases by at least the squared length of the input vector. 3. So after a finite number of mistakes, the weight vector must lie in the feasible region if the region exist. ## > **right feature** Once the hand-coded features have been determined, there are very strong limitations on what a perceptron can learn. _The main question is : This type of table look-up won't generalize, it need too many feature_ __ > Group Invariance Theorem---Minsky and Papert can't learn to do this if the transformations from a group{}so it needs to use multiple feature unit to recognize transformations of informative sub-patterns. So,more important was all about how you learn **feature detectors, that's hidden units**. After 20 years, We know, we need multiple layer of adaptive, non-linear hidden units.
Post.content:
• Recognizing pattern
    • Objects
    • facial
    • Spoken word
  • Recognizing anomalies
    • credit card transaction
    • Sensor reality
  • Prediction
    • stock price,
    • exchange rate
    • movie like

  • Linear neurons
    $ y=b+\sum x_iw_i $
  • Binary threshold neurons
  • Rectified Linear Neurons 2
  • sigmoid neurons
  • Stochastic binary neurons

  • supervised learning
    • Regression
      • model class: $y=f(x;w)$
      • 1/2
    • classification

  • reinforced learning

    the output is an action or sequence of actions and the only supervisory is an occasional scalar reward._This is difficult_, The rewads are typically delayed so its had to know where we went wrong( or right)

  • unsupervised learning

  • Feed-Forward neural network

    if there is more than one hidden layer, we call them deep neural networks.

  • Recurrent network

    It is hard to train but natural way for modeling sequence, recent algorithm can be able to do this, this also can be used to predict stock price.


    20171218 LSTM

  • Symmetrically connected networks

how to learn biases using the same rule as we use for learning weights

if the output unit is correct, leave its weights alone, if the output unit incorrectly output

  • Zy=1 perpendicular
  • $(w,b) \leftarrow (w,b)-(x,1)$
    $(w,b) \leftarrow (w,b)+(x,1)$
  • just like penalty function

: __

  1. Each time the perceptron makes a mistake, the current weight vector moves to decrease its squared distance from every weight vector in the generously feasible region.
  2. The squared distance decreases by at least the squared length of the input vector.
  3. So after a finite number of mistakes, the weight vector must lie in the feasible region if the region exist.

right feature

Once the hand-coded features have been determined, there are very strong limitations on what a perceptron can learn.
_The main question is : This type of table look-up wont generalize, it need too many feature_
__

Group Invariance Theorem-Minsky and Papert

cant learn to do this if the transformations from a group{}so it needs to use multiple feature unit to recognize transformations of informative sub-patterns.
So,more important was all about how you learn feature detectors, thats hidden units. After 20 years, We know,
we need multiple layer of adaptive, non-linear hidden units.

Post._content:
#   
## 
* 62210000
* train set 
* test set
* ML

## 
* dev set train set

## 
regularizer****
* L1
* L2Frobenius NormLambda
![nn_reg_12181821](http://p15i7i801.bkt.clouddn.com/2d81fcb8cfe1cb048929564aa91f9c4f.png)

* dropout
* 
    * Data augmentation
    * early stop: L2lambda

## normalize)
0-1w

## 

* RELU[](http://blog.csdn.net/mzpmzk/article/details/77418030)), $w$  $np.sqrt(\frac{2}{n^{[l-1]}+n^{[l]}})$
![ng_vanishing_exploding_grad](http://p15i7i801.bkt.clouddn.com/1f3a7fe0374fc7a514f6c69809520867.png)
#  
* Min-batch
* 
* Momentum:
$$ v_{dw} = \beta v_{dw} + (1-\beta)dw $$
$$ v_{db}=\beta v_{db} + (1-\beta)db $$
$$ w=w-\alpha v_{dw} $$
$$b=b-\alpha v_{db}$$
* RMSprop

$$ S_{dw} = \beta S_{dw} + (1-\beta){dw}^2 $$
$$ S_{db}=\beta S_{db} + (1-\beta){db}^2$$
$$ w=w-\alpha \frac{dw}{\sqrt{S_{dw}}}$$
$$ b=b-\alpha \frac{db}{\sqrt{S_{db}}}$$
* Adam(Adaptive Moment Estimation): Momentum and RMSprop
  * 
  $$ v_{dw} = \beta v_{dw} + (1-\beta_1)dw $$
  $$ v_{db}=\beta v_{db} + (1-\beta_1)db$$
  $$ S_{dw} = \beta S_{dw} + (1-\beta_2){dw}^2 $$
  $$ S_{db}=\beta S_{db} + (1-\beta_2){db}^2$$
  $$ w=w-\alpha \frac{v_{dw}}{\sqrt{S_{dw}}}$$
  $$ b=b-\alpha \frac{v_{db}}{\sqrt{S_{db}}}$$
  * 
      * $\alpha$ : needs to be tune
      * $\beta_1$ : (first momentum):0.9
      * $\beta_2$ : (second momnetum:RMSprop):0.99
* 
* saddleplateauAdam

#  Batch

## 
![ng_hp](http://p15i7i801.bkt.clouddn.com/149d38d31a5fa4e0576ff617c0408f08.png)
*  $\alpha$min-batch $\varepsilon$
* 
*  $\alpha$a log scala
  ```python
  r = -4*np.random.rand()
  alpha = 10^r
  ```

## 
* ****
* ****
* babysittingpandan: ****
* train in paraller: Caviar()

## normalizaion
![ng_batchnorm](http://p15i7i801.bkt.clouddn.com/eaa10f3214ad4cbd03b074755a13a8e0.png)

*  $\alpha\beta$ $Z^i$ 
* normalizaion
* andrew: Normalize $z$ rather than $a$

## Batch Norm
![ng_addBatchNorm](http://p15i7i801.bkt.clouddn.com/b398a029678304574bdf4e67d9ecc406.png)
* b $z^l=w^l a^{l-1}$

## Batch Norm
* 
* It makes weights, later or deeper than your network, more robost to changes to weights in earlier layers of neural netowork. **covariate shift**Batch Norm
* dropoutregularization.

## BatchNorm
* 
* ****
* batchnorm

## Softmax
,hard max $[1,0,0,0]$  $[0.8,0.2,0,0]$
![ng_softmax](http://p15i7i801.bkt.clouddn.com/6d6b110e436fb245d51cbf1179d231d2.png)

## Softmax
[](https://www.cnblogs.com/maybe2030/p/4751804.html#_label1) $w,b$
![ng_softmax_loss](http://p15i7i801.bkt.clouddn.com/4e804d7c109e9149bf95fc2df0603b14.png)

#  
* Min-batch
* 
* Momentum:
$$ v_{dw} = \beta v_{dw} + (1-\beta)dw $$
$$ v_{db}=\beta v_{db} + (1-\beta)db $$
$$ w=w-\alpha v_{dw} $$
$$b=b-\alpha v_{db}$$
* RMSprop

$$ S_{dw} = \beta S_{dw} + (1-\beta){dw}^2 $$
$$ S_{db}=\beta S_{db} + (1-\beta){db}^2$$
$$ w=w-\alpha \frac{dw}{\sqrt{S_{dw}}}$$
$$ b=b-\alpha \frac{db}{\sqrt{S_{db}}}$$
* Adam(Adaptive Moment Estimation): Momentum and RMSprop
  * 
  $$ v_{dw} = \beta v_{dw} + (1-\beta_1)dw $$
  $$ v_{db}=\beta v_{db} + (1-\beta_1)db$$
  $$ S_{dw} = \beta S_{dw} + (1-\beta_2){dw}^2 $$
  $$ S_{db}=\beta S_{db} + (1-\beta_2){db}^2$$

  *

### PCASVD
http://blog.csdn.net/jacke121/article/details/59057192
pcaSVD
SVD$A=U\Sigma V^T$U,V

SVD1231-22-31-2
$$U_k \Sigma V=> A^T U_k \Sigma$$
**PCA**

### 

* Apriori

### 
> SVM $w$ 

```python
def calcWs(alphas, dataArr, classLabels):
    """
    alphas, , 
    w
    """
    X = mat(dataArr)
    labelMat = mat(classLabels).transpose()
    m, n = shape(X)
    w = zeros((n, 1))
    for i in range(m):
        w += multiply(alphas[i] * labelMat[i], X[i, :].T)
    return w
```
, $w= \Sigma \alpha y_i x_i$ 
```python
w += multiply(alphas[i] * labelMat[i], X[i, :].T)
```
$y=(\Sigma \alpha y_i x_i) x + b$ 
![aiml-weightbook](http://p15i7i801.bkt.clouddn.com/c9fb298cf712884a5ad1c6d2407c4b95.png)
 $y=\Sigma \alpha y_i k(\phi(x_i),\phi(x_j))+b$ $w$ 

> weights = weights + alpha * dataMatrix.transpose() * error 

* http://blog.csdn.net/lu597203933/article/details/38468303  AndrewNg
![aiml-weight](http://p15i7i801.bkt.clouddn.com/79f4eb72472afa25f82690b0823b603d.png)
*  http://blog.csdn.net/aichipmunk/article/details/9382503

Post.title: draft
Post._content:
# 
*  $(A,S,R,P)$

*  $\pi$  $a$, 
  $$
  \begin{cases}
  \pi(s) \implies a \\
  \pi(a|s)
  \end{cases}
  $$
* [](http://www.cnblogs.com/jinxulin/p/3517377.html),
  $$ \{s_1,a_1,r_1,s_2,a_2,r_2,...,s_t,a_t,r_t\} $$
*  $G_t$ $G_t=\sum_{k=0}^N\gamma^kr_{k+t}$, 
$$
V_\pi(s)=E_\pi(G_t|S_t=s)  \\
Q_\pi(s,a)=E_\pi(G_t|S_t=s,A_t=a)
$$
* [Bellman](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bellman_equation)RL
$$
\mbox{ }V_\pi(s)=\sum\pi(a|s)E[R_{t+1}+\gamma V(s_{t+1})|S_t=s]  \\
 V_*(s)=E[R_{t+1}+\gamma max_\pi V(s_{t+1})|S_t=s]  \\
 Q_*(s,a)=E[R_{t+1}+\gamma max_{a^\prime} Q(s_{t+1},a^\prime)|S_t=s,A_t=a]
$$
*  $V_\pi$, $s$ $\pi$ $\pi^*=arg_\pi \{maxV_\pi(s)\}$[](http://www.cnblogs.com/jinxulin/p/3517377.html)

  $$ \{s_1,a_1,r_1,s_2,a_2,r_2,...,s_t,a_t,r_t\} $$
*  $G_t$ $G_t=\sum_{k=0}^N\gamma^kr_{k+t}$, 
$$
V_\pi(s)=E_\pi(G_t|S_t=s)  \\
Q_\pi(s,a)=E_\pi(G_t|S_t=s,A_t=a)
$$
* [Bellman](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bellman_equation)RL
$$
\mbox{ }V_\pi(s)=\sum\pi(a|s)E[R_{t+1}+\gamma V(s_{t+1})|S_t=s]  \\
 V_*(s)=E[R_{t+1}+\gamma max_\pi V(s_{t+1})|S_t=s]  \\
 Q_*(s,a)=E[R_{t+1}+\gamma max_{a^\prime} Q(s_{t+1},a^\prime)|S_t=s,A_t=a]
$$
*  $V_\pi$, $s$ $\pi$ $\pi^*=arg_\pi \{maxV_\pi(s)\}$[](http://www.cnblogs.com/jinxulin/p/3517377.html)
